raw_text:
Clarke to unveil immigration plan
 
 New controls on economic migrants and tighter border patrols will be part of government plans unveiled on Monday.
 
 Home Secretary Charles Clarke wants to introduce a points system for economic migrants and increase deportations of failed asylum seekers. Tony Blair has said people are right to be concerned about abuses of the system but there is no "magic bullet". The Tories say Labour is acting too late while the Lib Dems say the plans may not produce an efficient system.
 
 The government's new five-year plan is designed to show how Labour would reform immigration and asylum controls if it wins the election, expected to be held in May. Ministers deny they have been spurred into action by Tory campaigning or because the prime minister is worried too little has been done.
 
 Instead, they say the plans are part of an "evolving" process aimed at winning public confidence. Mr Clarke is expected to announce an end to the automatic right to settle for immigrants' families, and the introduction of fingerprinting for all visa applicants. The prime minister on Sunday said immigration would be "toughened up" to ensure only those immigrants with skills the UK really needs will be granted work permits. But he rejected the Tories' call for a quota on economic migrants, saying no "arbitrary figure" could reflect the UK's needs.
 
 Mr Blair told BBC Radio 4's Westminster Hour: "We should cut the number or increase it depending on the country's needs... "The public are worried about this, they are worried rightly, because there are abuses of the immigration and asylum system." But he defended the UK's current regime, saying all systems around the world were subject to abuse. Tory proposals to cap the number of asylum seekers and process all claims abroad would not work, argued Mr Blair.
 
 He said: "We will not be... pretending there is some simple easy way of processing Britain's asylum seekers in some other country, because no such other country exists." Conservative shadow home secretary David Davis said the government had failed to remove 250,000 failed asylum seekers from the UK and limits on economic migrants had been a "shambles". "What we are seeing today is a rather panicky response from the government after eight years of failure," he said. Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Mark Oaten said Labour was right to reject the Tories' idea of quotas on asylum. But he said it was yet to be seen if Mr Clarke could deliver "a fair and efficient asylum system".
llama3.2:1b: Clarke unveils immigration plan with points system, tighter border patrols, and increased deportations for economic migrants. The government's five-year plan aims to reform immigration controls if Labour wins the election. Clarke denies being spurred on by Tory campaigning or worrying about not enough action taken. The plan includes ending automatic settlement rights and introducing fingerprinting for visa applicants, but rejects quotas for economic migrants.
llama3.2:3b: Charles Clarke to unveil immigration plan, including points system for economic migrants, tighter border patrols, and end to automatic settlement for immigrant families, with Prime Minister Tony Blair defending the UK's current regime against Tory proposals.
gemma2:2b: The UK government will unveil a five-year plan for immigration reform, including a points system for economic migrants, increased deportations of failed asylum seekers, fingerprinting for visa applicants, and an end to automatic settlement rights.  Prime Minister Blair emphasizes that the plans are part of an "evolving" process aimed at improving public confidence but also defends the current system against claims that it's being abused. Conservative shadow home secretary David Davis criticizes the government’s lack of progress on removing failed asylum seekers and suggests a quota-based approach for economic migrants would be ineffective. Liberal Democrat spokesman Mark Oaten welcomes the plan while questioning its efficiency in achieving fairness and efficiency in the asylum system.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The new government plans to introduce a points system for economic migrants and increase deportations of failed asylum seekers, while acknowledging there is no "magic bullet" solution. However, the Tories argue Labour has not acted quickly enough while the Lib Dems suggest changes may not be effective. The government's five-year plan aims to show it will reform immigration controls if elected, with a focus on winning public support through an "evolving" process of reforms aimed at improving immigration and asylum systems.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Home Secretary Charles Clarke unveils immigration plans aimed at reforming controls, including a points system for economic migrants and increased deportations of failed asylum seekers, following Labor Party criticism. This plan forms part of the government's campaign to improve public confidence in immigration policies ahead of May elections. Key changes include ending automatic rights for family members of immigrants, introducing fingerprint checks for all visa applicants, and increasing deportation rates for illegal immigrants. Prime Minister Tony Blair supports reforms but rejects cap proposals from Conservatives, arguing that no system can prevent abuse globally.
qwen2.5:3b: Clarke will unveil immigration plans, including a points-based system for economic migrants and increased deportations of failed asylum seekers. The government aims to show how Labour would reform controls if elected, though there are concerns about potential inefficiencies. Key proposals include ending the automatic right to settle for immigrant families and fingerprinting visa applicants. The prime minister has rejected Tory calls for quotas on economic migration but supported tougher immigration control based on need rather than numbers. Conservative critics argue that the government's current approach has failed, while Lib Dems express skepticism about Clarke’s ability to implement a fair system.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary should include:

1. The main points from the text, including key ideas and details.
2. A concise overview of the main arguments or claims made in the text.
3. Any additional information that is relevant to the topic but not essential to understanding the main points.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Clarke unveiling an immigration plan. Let me read through each part carefully.

First, the text talks about New controls on economic migrants and tighter border patrols being part of government plans. That's the main point. The Home Secretary, Charles Clarke, is introducing a points system for migrants and increasing deportations of those who failed asylum. Tony Blair said people are right to be concerned but there's no magic bullet.

Then, it mentions that the Tories say Labour is acting too late while the Lib Dems say the plans won't work. Clarke will announce ending the automatic right to settle and fingerprinting all visa applicants. The PM says immigration should be toughened up for those who need skills, but Blair said no arbitrary figure reflects UK needs.

Wait, did I get that right? It seems like Clarke is introducing changes to show how Labour would reform if they win the election in May. The Lib Dems are saying the plans might not work and are worried too little has been done. Instead of being spurred by Tory stuff or because PM isn't doing enough.

Also, Clarke's announcement on family settling and fingerprinting seems specific. Maybe I should make sure to include those details accurately. The government is working towards public confidence, not just their own issues with the system.

I think that covers the key points: Clarke unveiling changes, Blair's concerns about policies but focus on UK needs, Lib Dems opposing, and how the government is evolving.
</think>

Clarke unveils immigration plans introducing a points system for migrants and stricter border patrols. Blair criticizes the UK's current immigration system, emphasizing public concern over abuse. Lib Dems oppose quotas, while Clarke outlines changes to end automatic settling and introduce fingerprinting. The PM aims toughening immigration but Blair supports UK needs focused on those with essential skills. Lib Dems are worried about too little done, and the government is working for public confidence.
tinyllama:1.1b: Following the publication of a new immigration plan by Home Secretary Charles Clark, Tony Blair has stated that Britain is acting too late to address concerns over abuses in the system. The five-year plan designed to reform immigration and asylum controls if Labour wins the upcoming election will introduce fingerprinting for visa applicants, an end to automatic right of settlement for immigrant families, and toughening up of immigration to reflect UK needs. However, the prime minister has rejected the Torie's call for quotas on economic migrants, arguing no arbitrary figure could reflect UK's needs. Liberal Democrats criticize Labour for being too late in their plan to address concerns over abuses and demand a fair and efficient asylum system.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The Home Secretary, Charles Clarke, has unveiled plans for a new immigration control system that will involve restricting the number of economic migrants entering the UK and increasing the number of people allowed to remain in the country. This plan is part of his government's new five-year plan, which aims to reform immigration controls and show how Labour would do so if they win the upcoming election. The plans are designed to address concerns about abuses of the immigration system and to ensure that only those migrants with skills and experience necessary for the UK's economy are allowed to settle in the country.

Ministers have insisted that this plan is not a "magic bullet", as some critics have claimed, but rather a step in the right direction that will lead to an efficient and fair immigration system. The plans include the removal of automatic right to settle for economic migrants' families, the introduction of fingerprinting for all visa applicants, and the introduction of strict criteria for granting work permits. The Prime Minister has expressed concern about the issue of abuses in the immigration process, and he has also rejected the Tories' suggestion that a quota system would be used to limit the number of migrants entering the UK.

In response to these concerns, Mr. Clarke has defended the current regime of immigration controls by stating that all systems around the world are subject to abuse. He believes that all cases should be dealt with on a case-by-case basis, based on individual needs and circumstances. Mr. Blair, the Labour Party leader, has defended the UK's current regime but has also argued that it is not "arbitrary" to cap the number of asylum seekers admitted into the country. He claims that all countries have their own unique needs when it comes to processing migrants and that no system can be simple or easy to implement.

The Conservatives, on the other hand, have dismissed Mr. Blair's proposal for a cap on asylum seekers and process all claims abroad. They argue that there is not enough evidence to support such a measure and that it would only lead to more abuses of the system. The Liberal Democrats have also expressed their opposition to the plans, saying that Labour should not be pretending that there is a simple easy way to remove failed asylum seekers from the UK or limit their movement within the country.
phi:2.7b: New controls on economic migrants and tighter border patrols will be part of government plans unveiled by Home Secretary Charles Clarke, including a points system for economic migrants, increased deportations of failed asylum seekers, and the end of automatic right to settle for immigrant families. The plan is designed to reform immigration and asylum controls if Labour wins the election in May. However, critics argue that Labour's proposals may not be efficient or produce an effective solution. Prime Minister Tony Blair supports stricter measures but rejects the idea of quotas on economic migrants. The government claims that their plans are part of an evolving process to gain public confidence.
orca-mini:3b: The text summarizes the key points of the article, which is about the government's plan to reform immigration and asylum controls if Labour wins the election. The plans include introducing a points system for economic migrants and increasing border patrols and deportations. The government denies that they are spurred by Tory campaigning or due to concerns about the current system. They are part of an evolving process aimed at winning public confidence, and the government plans to cut the number of asylum seekers and process all claims abroad. The prime minister rejects the Tories' call for a quota on economic migrants and says all systems are subject to abuse. The Labour party is criticized by the Tories and the Lib Dems for not effectively managing the system.
hermes3:3b: Charles Clarke to unveil immigration plan with new controls on economic migrants, tighter border patrols & increased deportations.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Home Secretary Charles Clarke will unveil government plans on Monday, including new controls on economic migrants and tighter border patrols. The plan aims to show how Labour would reform immigration and asylum controls if they win the election expected in May. The five-year plan includes ending the automatic right to settle for immigrant families and introducing fingerprinting for all visa applicants. Prime Minister Tony Blair defended the current immigration system but acknowledged public concerns about abuses, stating that no arbitrary figure could reflect the UK's needs. Conservative David Davis criticized the government's response as panicky after eight years of failure in removing failed asylum seekers. Liberal Democrat Mark Oaten agreed with Labour's rejection of quotas on asylum but questioned Clarke's ability to deliver a fair and efficient system.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The UK government is set to unveil new immigration controls, including a points system for economic migrants, increased deportations of failed asylum seekers, and tighter border security. Home Secretary Charles Clarke will also propose ending the automatic right to settle for immigrants' families and introducing fingerprinting for visa applicants. Prime Minister Tony Blair acknowledged public concerns about system abuses but rejected Conservative calls for migrant quotas, arguing that immigration levels should reflect the country's needs. The Conservatives criticized Labour for acting too late and failing to remove 250,000 failed asylum seekers, while the Liberal Democrats questioned whether the new measures would create an efficient system. Labour insists the reforms are part of an ongoing process rather than a reaction to political pressure.
stablelm2:1.6b: UK Home Secretary Charles Clarke will unveil new immigration plans, which include a points system for economic migrants and increased border patrols. The government aims to reform immigration controls with their five-year plan, scheduled for May's election. This plan is designed to demonstrate the Labour party's intentions if they win. Clarke is expected to end the automatic right for immigrant family members' settlement, and introduce fingerprinting for all visa applicants. Prime Minister Tony Blair plans to toughen up immigration by only allowing those with skills needed in the UK to receive work permits. However, he rejected a quota on economic migrants due to arbitrary figures not being able :r applicable. Tory proposals to cap asylum seekers and process claims abroad won't work according to Blair. Conservative shadow home secretary David Davis criticized the government for their inability to remove failed asylum seekers from the UK and for having limited control over economic migrants.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Home Secretary Charles Clarke will unveil a five-year immigration plan on Monday, focusing on tighter border controls for economic migrants. The proposal includes a points system to evaluate potential immigrants based on skills needed by the UK and mandatory fingerprinting for visa applicants. Additionally, Clarke plans to end the automatic right of settlement for immigrants' families.

Prime Minister Tony Blair emphasizes that the government is addressing public concerns about system abuses, acknowledging that no other country can effectively process asylum seekers domestically due to lack of such countries. He rejects the Conservative call for a quota on economic migrants, stating that no arbitrary figure could reflect Britain's needs.

Conservative leader David Davis criticizes the government's handling of 250,000 failed asylum seekers and the ineffectiveness of existing limits on economic migrants as "panicky." Liberal Democrat Mark Oaten supports Labour's rejection of a quota system but remains uncertain about the plan's ability to create an efficient asylum process.
reference: But he said it was yet to be seen if Mr Clarke could deliver "a fair and efficient asylum system".Conservative shadow home secretary David Davis said the government had failed to remove 250,000 failed asylum seekers from the UK and limits on economic migrants had been a "shambles".Home Secretary Charles Clarke wants to introduce a points system for economic migrants and increase deportations of failed asylum seekers.Mr Blair told BBC Radio 4's Westminster Hour: "We should cut the number or increase it depending on the country's needs... "The public are worried about this, they are worried rightly, because there are abuses of the immigration and asylum system."Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Mark Oaten said Labour was right to reject the Tories' idea of quotas on asylum.Tony Blair has said people are right to be concerned about abuses of the system but there is no "magic bullet".Tory proposals to cap the number of asylum seekers and process all claims abroad would not work, argued Mr Blair.The government's new five-year plan is designed to show how Labour would reform immigration and asylum controls if it wins the election, expected to be held in May.
